messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:29): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: how is <!doctype html public "-//"aol hometown//html 3.0 transitional//en"> triggering HTML5 quirks?

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:32): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: After the second '"' it's in 'after DOCTYPE public identifier state', and the 'a' puts it into 'bogus DOCTYPE state', which ends up setting the correctness flag to 'incorrect', so it gets treated as quirks
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:36): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: oh, yeah, good point
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:38): Oh, I just realised why my downloader was failing to terminate for one particular site
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:38): That site is an infinitely long radio stream
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:39): hah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:39): yeah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:39): i've come across infinite pages before too
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:39): that's how i know there's an infinite number of <font> elements on the web
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:40): :D
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:52): Why has my /bin/grep become thousands of times slower than it should be?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:55): and only on my XML file of extracted doctypes, not on any other file I've tested?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:56): Oh, it goes thousands of times faster again if I set LANG=en_GB without the .UTF-8
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:58): even though it's perfectly fast on a different computer with LANG=en_GB.UTF-8
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:59): computers are odd.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:03): Probably has to do with matching stuff like \w
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:05): I was only doing "grep processed foo.xml"
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:08): Maybe it does some conversion to an internal representation or some other premature optimization anyway?

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:09): <!DOCTYPE "="&quot;" PUBLIC="PUBLIC" HTML="html" HTTP://WWW.W3.ORG/TR/XHTML1/DTD/XHTML1-STRICT.DTD="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd" 1.0="1.0" -//W3C//DTD="-//W3C//DTD" STRICT//EN="Strict//EN"
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:09): " XHTML="XHTML">
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:09): Hmm, I can guess how that happened
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:12): wow, what a mess
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:12): Whitespace is our friend, right?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:21): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: re your request for rewriting the outlining algorithm
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:21): you say
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:21): > This sweep should probably define what checkpoint data to
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:21): > store on each element that implements the HTMLHeaderElement interface to allow
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:21): > local recomputation.

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:22): can't i just say what i usually say, namely that at any time, the outline must match the results you would get from running the algorithm over the whole tree?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:22): i don't want to be the one defining how you are to do optimisations...
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:23): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: does stating that actually make the said optimization reasonably implementable?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:23): depends what the algorithm is
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:24): http://philip.html5.org/data/doctypes-2.html#%3C!doctype_html%3E - now with links to pages, at least for the obscurer doctypes
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:25): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I don't see how it would hurt to define the outline in terms of forward sweeps from a hn state
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:25): oh it wouldn't, and that's just a subset of defining it as part of a forward sweep in general
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:25): i'm just saying the spec shouldn't define ny algorithm twice
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:25): since the spec shouldn't be optimising
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:26): or rather, it should be optimising for lack of ambiguity
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:26): and adding two algorithms defeats that :-)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:26): the current section confuses me
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:26): hmm... i guess each sectioning element is effectively atomic in the algorithm...
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:26): that is, anything outside a section can't affect what's inside it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:26): and what's inside a section can only affect the relative position of further nested sections...
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:27): that's useful
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:27): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: surely a forward sweep algorith can be the only definition
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:27): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: that's what i plan to do
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:27): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: excellent. thanks
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:28): but your e-mail asked for one or two other things too, which i'm not sure i should necessarily do
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:28): actually i think what i quoted above is a non-issue, and your second requirement might already be met
